description: From Middle English mary, marow, marwe, marowȝ, from Old English mearg,  from Proto-West Germanic *maʀg, from Proto-Germanic *mazgą, *mazgaz, from Proto-Indo-European *mosgʰos. Compare West Frisian moarch, Dutch merg, German Mark, Swedish märg, Icelandic mergur, and also Russian мозг (mozg, “brain”), Persian مغز‎ (mağz, “brain”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The substance inside bones which produces blood cells.
examples: Turning back, then, toward the basement staircase, she began to grope her way through blinding darkness, but had taken only a few uncertain steps when, of a sudden, she stopped short and for a little stood like a stricken thing, quite motionless save that she quaked to her very marrow in the grasp of a great and enervating fear.

entries.meaning: (countable) A kind of vegetable like a large courgette/zucchini or squash.
examples: The finest European vegetables, cabbages, cauliflowers, potatoes, vegetable marrow, were lying in the market-hall, awaiting purchasers.
This patient will have a marrow today.

entries.meaning: (Tyneside, informal) A friend, pal, buddy, mate.
(Scotland or archaic) One of a pair; a match; a companion; an intimate associate.
examples: The moon’s my constant Mistresse& the lowlie owle my morrowe.The flaming Drake and yͤ Nightcrowe makemee musicke to my sorrowe.
